comments.author: 237dmitry
comments.body:
> works

I think it would be nice to save the downloaded file without specifying its name. Without processing URI.

```powershell
$url = [uri] "https://somesite/somefile.ext"
$url.Segments[-1]
```

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body: > I think it would be nice to save the downloaded file without specifying its name. Without processing URI. > > ```powershell > $url = [uri] "https://somesite/somefile.ext" > $url.Segments[-1] > ``` No argument that it would be nice. But not all URIs work like that. One photo site I'm on has URLs in the form "https://site.com/userFolder/PictureID/photographer" The extension isn't in the URL at all and the distinctive part is not the final one. The first is solvable by looking at the mime type but there are always going to be cases where the naming scheme defeats any attempt get a sensible output name. Its one for discussion - perhaps what you suggest suits a big majority and for the other cases people need to code something which isn't quite so tidy

comments.author: 237dmitry
comments.body:
> But not all URIs work like that.

This is clearly. Since this is not a file download program (like wget or aria2), there is no common solution.

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
> > But not all URIs work like that.
> 
> This is clearly. Since this is not a file download program (like wget or aria2), there is no common solution.

Some people will want to use it as a download program. 

If there is a solution which works most of the time it's a "Post a script to the gallery" answer. If there is a solution which works nearly 100% of the time it's an "include it in PowerShell" answer. So I'm trying to understand what the percentage is likely to be -  I make a lot of calls to things where the file name isn't easy to select, but I don't think I'm typical.

comments.author: 237dmitry
comments.body:
> If there is a solution which works most of the time it's a "Post a script to the gallery" answer

The thing is that there is no universal script. Usually it's not even a script, but a script block for a specific task right in the console.
Nevertheless, it would be possible to make the `-OutFile` parameter without necessarily specifying the saved file. If the file is not specified then the file name is taken from the last segment of the url and the file is saved in the current directory. I think it would be convenient (especially when the name is long and difficult to remember, and copying it is an additional action)
